questions.prompt: The v-i characteristic of an ideal diode consists of:
options: A) A straight line through the origin
C) The negative v-axis and the positive i-axis
D) The positive v-axis and the negative i-axis
questions.correctAnswer: C) The negative v-axis and the positive i-axis
questions.explanation: The ideal diode has i = 0 for v < 0 (negative v-axis) and v = 0 for i > 0 (positive i-axis). These two segments meet at the origin.

questions.prompt: When an ideal diode is forward conducting, it behaves as:
questions.explanation: In forward conduction, v = 0 and current flows freely. This is exactly the behaviour of a short circuit.

questions.prompt: When an ideal diode is reverse biased, it behaves as:
questions.explanation: In reverse bias, i = 0 regardless of the (negative) voltage. This is exactly the behaviour of an open circuit.

questions.prompt: A 10V source is in series with a 2 kohm resistor and an ideal diode (forward direction). The current is:
questions.explanation: Assuming forward conduction: diode = short circuit. i = V/R = 10/2000 = 5 mA. Check: i = 5 mA > 0, consistent. Answer is 5 mA.

questions.prompt: A -3V source is in series with a 1 kohm resistor and an ideal diode (forward direction). The current is:
questions.explanation: Try forward conduction: i = -3/1000 = -3 mA < 0. Inconsistent. Try reverse bias: i = 0, v_diode = -3V < 0. Consistent. So i = 0 mA.

questions.prompt: The first step in analysing an ideal diode circuit is:
options: A) Write KVL equations with the diode equation
B) Assume a state (conducting or blocking) for each diode
C) Calculate the power dissipated in the diode
questions.correctAnswer: B) Assume a state (conducting or blocking) for each diode
questions.explanation: The assume-and-check method begins by assuming each diode is either forward conducting (short) or reverse biased (open), then solving the resulting linear circuit and checking consistency.

questions.prompt: You assumed a diode is forward conducting and found i = -2 mA through it. What should you conclude?
options: A) The assumption is correct; current is -2 mA
B) The assumption is wrong; try reverse biased instead
C) The diode is in breakdown
D) The circuit has no valid solution
questions.correctAnswer: B) The assumption is wrong; try reverse biased instead
questions.explanation: Forward conduction requires i >= 0. Finding i = -2 mA < 0 means the forward-conducting assumption is inconsistent. You must try reverse biased.

questions.prompt: How much power does an ideal diode absorb?
questions.explanation: In reverse bias, i = 0 so p = vi = 0. In forward conduction, v = 0 so p = vi = 0. The ideal diode absorbs zero power in both modes.

questions.prompt: A circuit has two ideal diodes in parallel with opposite polarities, connected to a 5V source through a resistor. How many diodes conduct?
options: D) Cannot be determined without the resistor value
questions.explanation: With opposite polarities, one diode is forward biased and one is reverse biased for a given source polarity. The forward-biased one conducts (short circuit), forcing v = 0 across both. The other sees v = 0, which is consistent with reverse bias. So exactly one conducts.

questions.prompt: The ideal diode model differs from the A-Level diode model primarily because:
options: A) It has no forward voltage drop
C) It has infinite reverse leakage
D) It is a linear device
questions.correctAnswer: A) It has no forward voltage drop
questions.explanation: The ideal diode sets the turn-on voltage to zero (no 0.7V drop). It captures the switching behaviour (block vs conduct) without modelling the gradual turn-on of a real semiconductor diode.
